data.title: Add terminal quick picker
data.body:
- If you type in `term␣` in quick picker, you get a list of active terminals 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13241824/28395964-13632872-6cad-11e7-86fd-b208c429345c.png)

This is like viewPickerHandler, but only for terminal.

Addresses #29879 . Doesn't have a command attached to it yet for a keybinding.

data.title: Editor loses focus when you click or drag the window title bar
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:08:57.197Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 
jshint|dba|0.10.15
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.6

When editing a file, if you click or drag the window title bar, editor loses focus. You need to click in the editor window again to set focus and cursor position before being able to type again.

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Click anywhere in the editor window of currently open tab
2. Click on the window title bar or drag it

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: staleSaveError is a bad experience
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Win10.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open an existing file and make some edits.
2. Modify the file with another editor or write it with another program.
3. VS Code quietly when an edited file be modified externally.
4. `staleSaveError` popup when save the edited file in VS Code.

Expected results:
1. VS Code should not be quiet when an edited file be modified externally, it should popup an tip earlier to indicate the file has been modified externally, for avoid a greater merge conflict.
2. If possible, it should to guide more effectively or auto merge the conflicts (diff).
3. If possible, it should displaye an message (box / tip) to ask actions, like take current, take external, resolve the conflict, cancel (back to editing).
4. Allow the user to reload the file without saving, #17643.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Windows Explorer/Notepad have no issues with those folders and files.

I have OneDrive 2016 (Build 17.3.6955.0712).

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Language agnostic region folding
data.body:
I am using VSC to work on project written in assembly code.

The code sources are usually very long (several thousands lines of code), yes they should be probably be shorter and split into components, but that is the way it is at least now.

Indentation folding does not work in assembly, and the language aware folding does not work with assembly language.

The most practical way to do it is to use region folding tags. I haven't found any existing issue with this request so far.

Could you please consider adding support for recursive folding region tags (the standard tags #region and #endregion would be perfect). This needs to work when they are anywhere on the line, because they will be embedded inside a comment, usually a line starting with ; or * in my case.

The irony being more than twenty years, on my 16 bits machine I had an editor supporting that.

- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 64 bits

data.title: Messages like “Unable to activate XX analyzer”
data.body:
When I with vscode 1.14.1 in Windows 10 pro add the following extensions:

* C/C++ 0.12.0
* C/C++ Advanced List 0.2.3
* C/C++ Clang Command Adapter 0.2.2
* C# 1.11.0
* C++ Intellisense 0.2.2
* Code Runner 0.6.26
* Debugger for Chrome 3.1.6
* Git History (git log) 0.2.1

opening a C file will result in a dropdown with the following messages:

* Unable to activate Flexelint analyzer.
* Unable to activate CppCheck analyzer.
* Unable to activate Clang analyzer.

The error messages will not go away and appears every time I switch to an editor with a file with that extension.

* There are no clues on why those "analysers" could not be "activated".
* The error message reappears every time a file with some extension instead of only informing the user once.
* The error messages are partly covering the editor.
* There is no way to close a single line, the close button on each line has to be clicked.

Screenshots on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45160650/why-do-i-get-error-messages-like-unable-to-activate-xx-analyzer-in-vscode

data.title: More fluid tab reordering
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code and open multiple tabs.
2. Try to re-order the tabs or move them.
3. For expected behavior: see comparison between VS Code and Sublime for what I would consider "fluid" movements. VS Code tabs seem to use move and snap/lock type UI while sublime provide continuous movement/feedback.

Is this behavior likely to change? If not, what is the rationale here?

**VS Code:**
![vs code](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6527137/28337381-51c518d0-6bba-11e7-9c61-47c152e13ff4.gif)

**Sublime:**
![sublime](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6527137/28337383-576fa30e-6bba-11e7-8810-b8f64609a76a.gif)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Terminal does not highlight text matching search in 'less'
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14
- OS Version: OSX 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open vscode terminal
2. run `less /etc/group`
3. do a search for root user by typing `/root`

Expected Result:

Terminal highlights the word "root"

Actual Result:

Terminal scrolls to the next occurrence of "root" without highlight.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Type literals handled poorly by IntelliSense
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new file in TypeScript mode. File does not need to be part of a project.
2. Copy the code from this gist: https://gist.github.com/zackschuster/3172f3d85e04ea2619d86129d9b4ec60
3. Expected behavior is in comments

I left a comment in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25034 with some of this info, then after finding more problems I decided to post a new issue. I bring this up because issues here may indirectly affect that bug.

Basically, it seems that IntelliSense is given a lot of over-simplified information w/r/t type literals, none of which follows a reliable or even necessarily coherent theory; depending on the context, the same literal may be revealed as its primitive, as its type alias, or as a completely unrelated type alias (!!!) that just happens to share properties.

While none of this appears to have an impact on compile-time correctness, it does make navigating code with IntelliSense more cumbersome than it needs to be while losing an opportunity to use `keyof` and crew with vscode in really powerful ways.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Snippet JSON scope attribute
data.body:
In order to allow snippets to only be used when relevant allow snippets to declare what scope they are usable in.  

This could also use scope selectors like https://manual.macromates.com/en/scope_selectors

data.title: Find all references and Rename Symbol do not work with --allowJS = true
data.body:
Having the allowJS Typescript set to true, makes "Find all References" not work. Also, Rename Symbol just throws an error "Sorry, rename failed to execute."

- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add allowJs: true to compilerOptions in tsconfig.json
2. Reload Window
3. Try to "Find All References" on anything in a .ts file
4. Always returns no results
5. Remove allowJs option from tsconfig.json
6. Reload Window
7. Try to "Find All References" again and it works!



<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes
